G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to **G.L. c. 218, § 19**, as the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limits of the District Court and the events giving rise to this action occurred within Middlesex County.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in the **Lowell District Court** pursuant to **G.L. c. 223, § 2**, because the Premises are located in Lowell, Massachusetts, where the Defendant conducts business as a landlord.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under **G.L. c. 186, § 14**, a landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of leased premises is liable for actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718.proposition: The statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment protects tenants from serious interference with the use of their premises as a residence. See **Blackett v. Olanoff**, 371 Mass. 714, 718 (1977).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely concerns the statutory/implied covenant of quiet enjoyment in a residential context and holds that substantial noise and disturbances from a lounge, attributable to the landlord, constituted a breach amounting to constructive eviction and made the apartments not reasonably habitable. The court characterizes the tenants as having been “very substantially deprived” of quiet enjoyment, and emphasizes that tenants should not have to pay rent for residential premises under such serious interferences, which aligns with the stated proposition.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found that the tenants were ‘very substantially deprived’ of quiet enjoyment of their leased premises ‘for a substantial time’… He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: A landlord’s failure to remedy conditions that threaten health or safety constitutes a breach of this covenant. See **Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.**, 417 Mass. 273, 284 (1994); **Al-Ziab v. Mourgis**, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (1997).
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that a landlord’s failure to act to remedy conditions on the premises that seriously threaten tenants’ health or safety can constitute a breach of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment. The court explains that if the landlord “failed to take any action” to remove persons engaged in unlawful activity whose presence seriously interferes with tenants’ use of the premises, the landlord may be liable for breach. That directly supports the proposition that failure to remedy health‑ or safety‑threatening conditions breaches the covenant.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “If the defendant has failed to take any measures, especially those measures which can be undertaken relatively easily, to remove unwelcome persons from the property that it owns and controls, and the presence of those persons seriously interferes with the tenancy, then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (.proposition: A landlord’s failure to remedy conditions that threaten health or safety constitutes a breach of this covenant. See **Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.**, 417 Mass. 273, 284 (1994); **Al-Ziab v. Mourgis**, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (1997).
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (.support_reasoning: The court holds that liability under the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment requires at least negligent conduct by a landlord who has notice or reason to know of the dangerous condition and fails to take corrective measures. In explaining this, the opinion approvingly cites prior cases (including Doe) where a landlord’s failure to repair known defects was deemed a § 14 violation, making clear that unremedied conditions threatening health or safety can constitute a breach of the covenant. Thus, the case supports the proposition when read with the notice/negligence requirement.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (.relevant_excerpt: We noted that a landlord’s failure “to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.” See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so). Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord...

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: The existence of mold caused by improper ventilation constitutes a condition interfering with quiet enjoyment and habitability. See **Lowery v. Robinson**, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983 (1982) (unsanitary conditions impair tenant’s enjoyment).
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns lack of heat as a breach of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. It does not mention mold, ventilation problems, or unsanitary conditions generally, nor does it articulate a broader rule about “unsanitary conditions” impairing habitability. Using this case to support a proposition about mold from improper ventilation misstates its holding and scope.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season … seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. … Thus … liability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (198.proposition: Defendant’s refusal to correct the problem after notice constitutes an “act or omission” within the meaning of **G.L. c. 186, § 14**. See **Simon v. Solomon**, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1982).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion does interpret G.L. c. 186, § 14 broadly and holds that reckless (not just intentional) interference with quiet enjoyment is actionable, but it does not specifically frame a landlord’s post‑notice refusal to correct conditions as the required ‘act or omission.’ The discussion focuses on interference with quiet enjoyment via maintaining unsanitary, flood‑causing conditions, not on the distinct concept that a refusal to repair after notice, by itself, constitutes the statutory ‘act or omission.’ That more specific proposition is not expressly articulated at page 102 or elsewhere in the decision.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (198.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929) (quoting from Brande v. Grace, 154 Mass. 210, 212 [1891]). … When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’ … it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute.” (385 Mass. at 102).

105 C.M.R. \u00a7 410.750 et seq..proposition: Massachusetts law requires that rental housing be kept in compliance with the **State Sanitary Code** (**105 C.M.R. § 410.750 et seq.**), including obligations to maintain plumbing, ventilation, and freedom from mold or excessive moisture (**105 C.M.R. § 410.750–410.820**).

105 C.M.R. \u00a7 410.750\u2013410.820.proposition: Massachusetts law requires that rental housing be kept in compliance with the **State Sanitary Code** (**105 C.M.R. § 410.750 et seq.**), including obligations to maintain plumbing, ventilation, and freedom from mold or excessive moisture (**105 C.M.R. § 410.750–410.820**).

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7 127A.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain the Premises in compliance with the Sanitary Code also violates **G.L. c. 111, § 127A**, which defines such substandard conditions as deleterious to health and unlawful for occupancy.

McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304,.raw_text: McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304, 311 (1977)
McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304,.proposition: Where a landlord fails to correct such unsanitary conditions after notice, the tenant may recover for breach of quiet enjoyment. See **McKenna v. Begin**, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304, 311 (1977); **Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson**, 379 Mass. 196, 199–200 (1979).
McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304,.support_reasoning: The opinion deals exclusively with breach of the implied warranty of habitability and how to measure damages, not with breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Although it discusses State Sanitary Code violations and landlord notice, it never frames the claim as one for quiet enjoyment nor states that failure to correct unsanitary conditions after notice gives rise to such a claim. Using McKenna as authority for quiet enjoyment, rather than warranty of habitability, overreads the case.
McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304,.relevant_excerpt: “This case returns to us following its remand to the Superior Court for computation by the trial judge of the damages owed to a tenant by his landlord for breach of the implied warranty of habitability… the judge had awarded damages to the plaintiff McKenna against his landlord… for violations of the State Sanitary Code… We also ruled that damages were to be computed from the inception of the tenancy if it were shown that the defective conditions existed at that time. But, if the defects arose during the tenancy, damages were to be computed from the time when the landlord first knew or was notified of their existence.”

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 199–200 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: Where a landlord fails to correct such unsanitary conditions after notice, the tenant may recover for breach of quiet enjoyment. See **McKenna v. Begin**, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304, 311 (1977); **Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson**, 379 Mass. 196, 199–200 (1979).
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with lack of heat and hot water and the resulting breach of the implied warranty of habitability and rent abatement; it does not discuss unsanitary conditions as such or the statutory/common-law covenant of quiet enjoyment. The case reaffirms that substantial Sanitary Code violations can render a dwelling uninhabitable, but it frames the remedy as rent abatement for breach of the warranty of habitability, not damages for breach of quiet enjoyment after notice. Thus, citing Berman for the specific quiet-enjoyment proposition is inaccurate.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. The essential objective of the warranty is to make sure that the tenant receives what she is paying for. The tenant may not excuse her obligation with mere reasonable efforts to pay rent. Nor may the landlord avoid his duty with mere reasonable efforts to provide a habitable dwelling. The contract between the parties, seen through the law’s clarifying lens, requires such symmetry.”

Gorrasi v. C.P. Reilly & Sons, Inc., 13.raw_text: Gorrasi v. C.P. Reilly & Sons, Inc., 13 Mass. App. Ct. 431, 436 (1982)
Gorrasi v. C.P. Reilly & Sons, Inc., 13.proposition: The Defendant’s failure to act substantially deprived Plaintiff of the beneficial use of the apartment by forcing her to live in unsafe and unhealthy conditions. See **Gorrasi v. C.P. Reilly & Sons, Inc.**, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 431, 436 (1982).
Gorrasi v. C.P. Reilly & Sons, Inc., 13.case_name: Warren Brothers Co. v. Sentry Ins.
Gorrasi v. C.P. Reilly & Sons, Inc., 13.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns allocation of payments among multiple debts and the rights of a surety versus a creditor; it has nothing to do with residential tenancies, habitability, or a landlord’s failure to act causing unsafe or unhealthy living conditions. The quoted pages address contract and surety law, not deprivation of the beneficial use of an apartment. Thus, citing this case for a proposition about unsafe housing conditions and loss of beneficial use of an apartment is inaccurate and unsupported by the decision.
Gorrasi v. C.P. Reilly & Sons, Inc., 13.relevant_excerpt: "We think it more equitable to view any interest that the surety may have in the application of the funds as simply another factor to be weighed by the court in making its determination. In assessing Sentry’s claim of entitlement to the benefit of the payment, we especially note that there is nothing in the contract between Healy and Warren which obligated Warren to credit the Quincy project for any payments received from the proceeds of that contract."

105 C.M.R. \u00a7\u00a7 410.600\u2013410.proposition: Massachusetts law requires that rental housing be kept in compliance with the **State Sanitary Code** (**105 C.M.R. § 410.750 et seq.**), including obligations to maintain plumbing, ventilation, and freedom from mold or excessive moisture (**105 C.M.R. § 410.750–410.820**).
